title: In the Money vs Out of the Money

screens.headline: This determines if your option has ANY value
screens.text: Two traders buy calls on the same stock. One is 'in the money' and safe. The other is 'out of the money' and needs a miracle. The difference? Just $5 in strike price. This matters more than you think.

screens.headline: The Three States of Options
screens.text: Every option is always in one of three states: IN THE MONEY (ITM) = has intrinsic value right now. AT THE MONEY (ATM) = strike equals stock price. OUT OF THE MONEY (OTM) = zero intrinsic value, needs movement to profit.

cards.definition: Option has intrinsic value if exercised now
cards.example: Stock $110, call strike $100 = $10 ITM. Stock $90, put strike $100 = $10 ITM. Has real value TODAY.

cards.definition: Strike price equals current stock price
cards.example: Stock $150, call or put strike $150 = ATM. No intrinsic value yet, but closest to the action. Most liquid.

cards.definition: Option has zero intrinsic value, only time value
cards.example: Stock $100, call strike $120 = OTM. Worthless if exercised now. Needs stock to rise $20+ to profit.

screens.headline: Think of it like a race
screens.text: You bet on a runner. The finish line is 1 mile away. There are 3 different betting scenarios based on where your runner is NOW...

reveal_sections.label: Runner at 0.9 miles (almost there)
reveal_sections.content: IN THE MONEY = Your runner is close to winning. Even if they walk, they'll probably finish. Expensive bet, but safer. This is ITM.

reveal_sections.label: Runner at 0.5 miles (halfway)
reveal_sections.content: AT THE MONEY = Your runner is mid-race. Could win, could lose. Fair price for fair odds. This is ATM - balanced risk/reward.

reveal_sections.label: Runner at 0.1 miles (barely started)
reveal_sections.content: OUT OF THE MONEY = Your runner needs a miracle. Cheap bet, but low odds. If they win, massive payout. High risk. This is OTM.

reveal_sections.label: Options work the same way
reveal_sections.content: ITM = safer, expensive. ATM = balanced. OTM = risky, cheap. Your strike price determines which 'zone' you're in.

screens.question: TSLA is at $250. You own a $230 call. Is this ITM, ATM, or OTM?
screens.explanation_correct: Correct! Stock at $250, call strike $230 = you can buy at $230 when market is $250. That's $20 of intrinsic value. You're IN THE MONEY. This call has real value even if you exercised right now.
screens.explanation_wrong: For CALLS: ITM when stock ABOVE strike. Stock at $250, strike $230 = stock is $20 higher. If you exercised now, you'd buy at $230 and immediately have $250 stock. That's $20 intrinsic = ITM.

screens.question: AAPL at $180. You own a $200 put. Is this ITM, ATM, or OTM?
screens.explanation_correct: Yes! Stock at $180, put strike $200 = you can SELL at $200 when market is $180. That's $20 intrinsic. You're IN THE MONEY. This put is profitable right now.
screens.explanation_wrong: For PUTS: ITM when stock BELOW strike. Stock at $180, strike $200 = stock is $20 lower. If you exercised now, you'd sell at $200 when market is $180. That's $20 instant profit = ITM.

screens.question: You're choosing between: A) $150 call (ITM, $10 premium) or B) $170 call (OTM, $2 premium). Stock at $160. Which is safer?
options: Option A - already has intrinsic value
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Option A already has $10 intrinsic ($160 stock - $150 strike). Even if stock doesn't move, it retains value. Option B needs stock above $170 just to have intrinsic value. ITM = safer but costs more.
screens.explanation_wrong: ITM options are safer because they ALREADY have intrinsic value. The $150 call has $10 of value TODAY. The $170 call needs the stock to rise $10 just to break even. When safety matters, pay up for ITM.

screens.question: NVDA at $500. You want max leverage and are willing to risk it all. Which call?
options: $550 call (OTM) - cheap but needs big move
screens.explanation_correct: High risk/reward play! The $550 call is cheap ($1-2), but if NVDA pops to $580, you make 500%+. This is speculation, not investing. Only risk money you can lose. OTM = leverage for small accounts.
screens.explanation_wrong: For MAX LEVERAGE: OTM options give you the most bang for your buck. $550 call might cost $200 vs $3,000 for ITM. If you're right about a big move, OTM returns are exponential. But... 70% of OTM options expire worthless. Know the risk!

screens.question: META at $320. You're looking at a $340 call. How many dollars OTM is this call? (Answer as a number only)
screens.hint: For calls: OTM amount = Strike - Stock Price (if strike is higher)
screens.explanation: $340 strike - $320 stock = $20 out of the money. The stock needs to rise $20 just for this call to have ANY intrinsic value. That's why OTM calls are cheaper - they need movement.

cards.back: ITM = stock ABOVE strike (already profitable). OTM = stock BELOW strike (needs to rise). ATM = stock equals strike. Think: 'In' = already winning.
ITM = stock BELOW strike (already profitable). OTM = stock ABOVE strike (needs to fall). Opposite of calls. Think: puts profit from drops.
ITM = safer, expensive, behaves like stock. ATM = balanced. OTM = high risk/reward, needs big moves. Match to your conviction and risk tolerance.

screens.badge_description: You understand ITM, ATM, and OTM!
screens.celebration_message: Great work! You now know which options have value and which need movement. Next: why your options lose value every single day.
